item.title: After Six Decades of the War on Drugs, What Works?
item.description: The U.S. and its allies have spilled blood and treasure to kill drug lords and defeat cartels, but the drugs keep coming and the new groups are more violent than ever.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: Cesar Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A burned car in Guadalajara following the capture and killing of Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes.

item.title: After Chaos Rips Across Mexico, the Remnants of Cartel Violence Haunt Residents
item.description: Charred vehicles cluttered deserted streets as residents started to emerge from their homes in Guadalajara, which was hit hard by violence after the death of a cartel leader.
item.dc:creator: Paulina Villegas and César Rodríguez
item.media:credit: César Rodríguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Empty streets and closed businesses on Monday in downtown Guadalajara.

item.title: Hunkering Down in Mexico, Some Hope for a Flight Out Amid Burning Cars
item.description: People from Canada and the United States tell of scrambling for safety, food and flights after violence erupted in Mexico when a cartel boss died in custody.
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla
item.media:description: Tourists watching a smoke rising after cartel members blocked roads and burned down businesses after a military operation led to the death of the Mexican drug lord Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico.

item.title: Canada to Probe What OpenAI Knew About Tumbler Ridge Shooter
item.description: The company suspended the killer’s ChatGPT account over a policy violation in June, eight months before the attacks in Tumbler Ridge, British Columbia.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Alana Paterson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial for the victims of a the mass shooting this month at Tumbler Ridge Secondary School in British Columbia.

item.title: Mexican Forces Say They Tracked El Mencho to Cabin by Following His Lover
item.description: Top security officials revealed details of the operation that led to the death of Mexico’s most wanted drug cartel leader.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:description: Gen. Ricardo Trevilla Trejo, Mexico’s defense minister, described this weekend’s operation against a top cartel leader at a news conference in Mexico City on Monday with President Claudia Sheinbaum.

item.title: C.I.A. Intelligence Helped Lead Mexican Authorities to ‘El Mencho’
item.description: Mexican officials said they had found the elusive cartel kingpin by tracking a romantic partner. The C.I.A. provided some intelligence critical to the operation.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt and Jack Nicas
item.media:description: Mexican special forces in Mexico City on Sunday. C.I.A. intelligence helped lead the special forces to the cartel leader.

item.title: Videos Show How Violence Unfolded in Mexico After Killing of Cartel Boss
item.description: Armed groups blocked roads and set fire to supermarkets and banks after the Mexican government killed Mexico’s most-wanted cartel boss.
item.dc:creator: Devon Lum and Pablo Robles

item.title: What Travelers Need to Know as Cartel Violence Rattles Mexico
item.description: The killing of a drug lord and the unrest that followed have prompted flight cancellations, roadblocks, cruise disruptions and “shelter in place” alerts.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Hiltner
item.media:description: Mayhem after the killing of Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes, who led a powerful criminal group, disrupted flights at Guadalajara International Airport on Sunday.

item.title: Puerto Vallarta Jolted By Violence After Cartel Boss Killing
item.description: When violence broke out after the killing of Mexico’s most-wanted cartel boss, vacation spots ordinarily spared from the drug wars were also targeted.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and David Shortell
item.media:description: Firefighters work to extinguish a bus on fire in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, Sunday.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and James Wagner

item.title: Supreme Court Considers Fate of Docks and Other Assets Seized by Cuba in 1960
item.description: Amid rising tensions with Cuba, the Trump administration is backing lawsuits that would allow Americans to get compensation for property confiscated by Fidel Castro’s regime.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow
item.media:description: Revolutionaries confiscated the property of the Havana Docks Company in 1960.

item.title: Drug Lord ‘El Mencho’ Was Killed in Mexico. What’s Next for the Cartel He Led?
item.description: The death of Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes dealt a major blow to the Jalisco New Generation Cartel, but few believe it spells the end for the powerful group.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:description: Security forces patrolling in Mexico City after the killing of Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes on Sunday.

item.title: What to Know About the Killing of ‘El Mencho’
item.description: The Mexican government has killed Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes, the longtime leader of one of Mexico’s most powerful gangs, the Jalisco New Generation Cartel.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Firefighters extinguishing a burning bus blocking a roadway in Jalisco state, Mexico, on Sunday.

item.title: ‘This Has Been a Day:’ U.S.-Canada Hockey Game Puts Rivalry on the Line
item.description: Canadians and Americans jammed bars that opened early on Sunday to watch the United States deal the Canadian team, and the country, a devastating blow in overtime.
item.dc:creator: Shawna Richer and Rylee Kirk
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
item.media:description: At the Canuck in Manhattan on Sunday, a handful of U.S. fans watched among a largely pro-Canada crowd.

item.title: ‘The Waterfall’ Review: A Mother’s Blessing and a Daughter’s Burden
item.description: Phanésia Pharel’s wistful two-hander starring Patrice Johnson Chevannes and Natalie Paul looks at a Haitian American family and questions of legacy.
item.dc:creator: Rhoda Feng

item.title: Mexican Forces Kill ‘El Mencho,’ Nation’s Most-Wanted Cartel Boss
item.description: “El Mencho” was the longtime head of one of the nation’s most powerful cartels. Armed groups set fire to cars and buildings across Mexico in the wake of his death.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Paulina Villegas
item.media:description: Agentes de policía aseguran una zona en la que miembros del crimen organizado incendiaron vehículos en Zapopan, México, el domingo.

item.title: Fat Signing Bonuses, and Concierge Service, for Family Doctors
item.description: In a country where a quarter of the population lacks a family doctor, Canadian communities compete in a zero-sum battle to recruit family doctors.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Gavin John
item.media:credit: Gavin John for The New York Times
item.media:description: The town of Stettler, Alberta’s economy is predominantly driven by the agriculture and oil industries, and is the largest town for surrounding communities.

item.title: Supreme Court Ruling on Trump’s Tariffs Changes Little for Canada
item.description: The president’s tariffs that are inflicting the most harm to Canada’s economy are outside the scope of the Supreme Court case.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: The 50 percent tariffs on Canadian steel that have led to layoffs at Algoma Steel are not affected by the court decision.

item.title: How $600 Drones Are Outsmarting Colombia’s Billion-Dollar Military
item.description: Security officials say easy access by guerrilla groups to commercial drones, cheaply modified into deadly weapons, has put the nation’s army on its heels.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak and Simón Posada
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Robinson Hernandez and John Silva, who work for a company that specializes in drone and anti-drone technology, using devices to neutralize drones during a test in Bogotá, Colombia.

item.title: Venezuela Releases Political Prisoners, With Conditions
item.description: Since Nicolás Maduro’s capture by the United States, Venezuela has released hundreds of political prisoners and approved a new amnesty law, although the restrictions on those freed have raised questions about whether this signals real change. Our international correspondent Simon Romero describes what’s happening.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero, Leila Medina, Melanie Bencosme, June Kim, Patricia Sulbarán, Marian Carrasquero and Isayen Herrera

item.title: A New U.S. Blockade Is Strangling Cuba
item.description: An analysis of ship movements shows that the Trump administration is isolating the island at one of its most vulnerable moments.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Christiaan Triebert
item.media:description: The oil tanker Ocean Mariner at the port of Havana last month. Cuba is facing the United States’ first effective blockade since the Cuban Missile Crisis.

item.title: Why the United States Is Seeing an Ongoing Tourism Slump
item.description: Last year, the U.S. was the only major destination to see a decline in international travelers. With increased scrutiny at the border, ICE violence and unpredictable policies, the new year isn’t looking better.
item.dc:creator: Ceylan Yeğinsu
item.category: Disney, Walt, World (Lake Buena Vista, Fla)
item.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Passengers and crew walk to a Transportation Security Administration security checkpoint at Los Angeles International Airport in November.

item.title: Venezuela Passes Amnesty Bill Denounced by Some as ‘Unjust’
item.description: The bill may bring the release of hundreds of political prisoners. But many critics say the legislation, passed after major pressure from the Trump administration, raises concerns.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak, Annie Correal, Patricia Sulbarán, Isayen Herrera and Genevieve Glatsky
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Families gathered last month for a vigil outside El Rodeo I, a prison east of Caracas, Venezuela.

item.title: In Guadeloupe, the Caribbean’s Best-Kept Secret, Every Beach Is Better Than the Last
item.description: In Guadeloupe, a land of volcanoes, rainforests and hot springs, you may find yourself canceling your other plans so you can explore just one more hidden cove.
item.dc:creator: Mya Guarnieri and Tony Cenicola

item.title: University of British Columbia Professors Sue School Over Political Correctness
item.description: A group of academics at the University of British Columbia say the school’s D.E.I. policies and practices, which include land acknowledgments, violate a law that requires universities to be “nonpolitical.”
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar and Alana Paterson
item.media:credit: Alana Paterson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A post carved by the Musqueam artist Brent Sparrow Jr. on the University of British Columbia campus in Vancouver.

item.title: Alysa Liu Is Skating Again, Her Way This Time
item.description: At 16, out of love with the sport, Liu stepped away. On Thursday, she became the first American to win individual gold in women’s figure skating in 24 years.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur

item.title: Peru Votes to Impeach President José Jerí
item.description: Peru’s Congress voted to impeach President José Jerí, four months after he replaced Dina Boluarte, who had also been removed from the presidency.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky and Mitra Taj
item.media:description: José Jerí was sworn in last October as interim president, replacing Dina Boluarte.
